data.title: audio panning doesn't work
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10
godot 2.1.3
sound: 
AMD High Definition Audio Device
Realtek High Definition Audio 

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Changed panning of a voice playing on a sample player. Sound stays the same in both ears. 
Sometimes it works, if I leave my PC for an hour and come back and hit play, panning works. The next time I run it it won't work.
 Restarting godot editor doesn't fix it, and neither does exporting it as a build and running the exe.
I've run several audio tests on youtube and the panning works in my headphones.

**Steps to reproduce:**
create a project with a sample player playing a track on loop, add some controls to change the panning in real time.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
Use left and right arrows to adjust panning
[audiopantest.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1254498/audiopantest.zip)

data.title: Adapt docs background to Highlight theme.
Suggestion: Create Sprite dragging to Scene panel
data.body:
Dragging an image resource from the FileSystem panel onto a node in the Scene panel should create a Sprite node whose texture is the dragged file, where its position is 0, 0 relative to its parent.

My reasoning is thus:
1. This behavior is intuitive, and having more ways to do the same thing accommodates more users.
2. It doesn't override any existing behavior.
3. To my knowledge, the fastest existing way to create a Sprite child node at 0, 0 with the desired texture (which IMO is the most common desire for Sprites) is to use the manual insert child node menu, selecting Sprite, and choosing the texture property manually; or to drag the texture resource to the editor while its desired parent is selected, and then manually changing the position to 0, 0 in the Inspector panel.

data.title: Fix RtAudio driver buffer_size incorrect calculation
data.body:
Should fix #10644 and #7288.
Previous to this PR the audio buffer size was resulting too small on the RtAudio driver, and this triggered the underflow warnings.

data.title: Cleaned up logic in Tween::_tween_process(), fixes #9187
data.body:
Fixes the issue of `tween_complete` not being emitted for `interpolate_callback()`/`interpolate_deferred_callback()`.
The logic was also cleaned up a bit to make it, IMHO, more clear.

This issue is also present in the master branch but I'm submitting this PR to the 2.1 branch as I think it'd be nice to get in to 2.1.4 before the release candidate period is up.

data.title: Viewport: fix 'size' binding from Rect2 to Vector2
data.body: Brought to attention by @letheed [here](https://github.com/godotengine/godot-docs/pull/446).

data.title: Vertex color "use as albedo" is ignored when emission is white
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits
nVidia 940M

I created a mesh with PRIMITIVE_LINES, but I am unable to make it output vertex color as emission. I enabled "use vertex color as albedo", but then it's shaded. If I set emission to white, it becomes white and ignores vertex color.
Related? https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/10441

Workaround: set the mesh as unshaded.

data.title: Use memset to zero z_list
data.body:
Using gprof I found the engine spending 10 - 20% of time in the
_render_canvas_item_tree function. The function profiles as using
about 0.09ms. Swapping the loop with two memset() calls reduces
the time spent in this function a lot, and the time per call to
about 0.02ms.
    
Likewise the render_canvas function was using ~10% of time, replacing
the loop there dropped per-call time from 0.22ms to 0.18ms.

This profiling was done on the platformer 2d demo.

data.title: Godot saves scenes over others, producing data loss and stack overflows
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits

For some reason, I managed to save my main scene over another scene that was contained in the main scene, causing a circular reference:
```
main.tscn --> references character.tscn
character.tscn
```
Became:
```
main.tscn --> references character.tscn
character.tscn --> references character.tscn (because character.tscn contents became the same as main.tscn)
```
So I lost my character.tscn \o/ no idea how that happened.
I reverted character.tscn, now the project loads fine! Then I played again: re-stack overflow. Investigating...

**Second breakthrough:
I didn't dream, Godot just saved a scene over another, this time I lost the main scene completely, replaced by character.tscn contents D:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29746239-f7a1d968-8ad3-11e7-90c0-0508fc763426.png)
I have two main scenes now (stored in files with different names though)

Repro steps:
1) Create a new project
2) Create a scene, save it as `a.tscn`
3) Create another scene in a second tab, save it as `b.tscn`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29746333-a2d27fa2-8ad6-11e7-86e9-2263ae12396f.png)
4) Click on scene `a`, hit Play, select the scene as main one etc
5) Click on scene `b`, hit Play: notice both scene tabs have the same name:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29746329-8927e024-8ad6-11e7-953b-395f73bd5874.png)
6) If you attempt to click on the first tab and Play, Godot will save the contents of `b.tscn` over `a.tscn` when auto-save occurs (not sure yet if that's exactly what happens, but it happens shortly after I see both tabs named the same)

data.title: Script editor background is too clear / doesn't apply
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits

I know this is subjective, but maybe it wasn't intented: the script editor background recently became brighter, same color as all other docks. As a result, text contrast became lower, it think it doesn't look good when coding.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29745602-8f515ad2-8abf-11e7-939a-dd8c484a745f.png)

Maybe it's related to this, when I open the picker for "background color", I see it's supposed to be black with some alpha:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29745620-1c369d36-8ac0-11e7-967a-0b2b2d57cf21.png)


If people prefer it to stay like this I'll probably crank down my background setting anyways... but maybe it's a bug?
Edit: I tried to change background color and I confirm it just doesn't apply.

data.title: Shadows don't show by default, or are lower quality
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits
nVidia 940M

I noticed shadows weren't visible with default DirectionalLight setup. I can only see them when I reduce bias from 1 to 0.1, or reduce distance considerably (from 200 to 10) and it shows very low quality shadows:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/29745343-668cd24a-8ab8-11e7-99f7-8456a78c41e3.png)

Even though shadows still work, something might have changed recently that made shadows lower quality by default? Or is it my imagination?

data.title: Add two missing Null checks
data.body:
These Null checks were removed in #10581 but actually changed the
logic of the functions in this case.

This fixes #10654

data.title: EditorHelp: Fixes desc of vararg methods
data.body:
Removes extra comma at the beginning when the method does not have arguments:

`void call_func(, ... ) vararg` -> `void call_func( ... ) vararg`

Includes `...` in the signature of method descriptions:

`void call_func() vararg` -> `void call_func( ... ) vararg`
`void emit_signal( String signal ) vararg` -> `void emit_signal( String signal, ... ) vararg`

data.title: Add several missing Null checks in _notification
data.body: This fixes #6118

data.title: Particles2d random initial velocity doesn't seem to do anything
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot v3.0.alpha.custom_build.3ae1cff

**Issue description:**
1. ~~Particles2D has a texture property with horizontal/vertical divisions. It implies it can use a picture, split it in tiles and randomly choose from those tiles. This does not happen, only first tile is used.~~ (done by ddadc78)
2. random initial velocity doesn't seem to do anything

See attached project: [godot-dbg.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1253958/godot-dbg.zip)

*edit:* Oh, and:
~3. if particles system isn't inside screen area it doesn't seem to work, particles should be emitted even if particle system outside of the rendering region (screen), like in the example above, you want the clouds to form before entering the picture, just try moving the particle system outside of the screen and run the project~

nevermind 3... I guess it has to do with the visibility rect setting

data.title: Added freelook inertia
data.body:
As mentionned in https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10463#issuecomment-325148756
It's nice to have because unlike mouse-based navigation, keyboard movement is all-or-nothing, so it makes it smoother.

Here is a video of the inertia I implemented:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jFpizpEM5o8&feature=youtu.be
It's basically a setting where 0 = no inertia, and the higher it is, the more inertia it applies.
It's still based on lerp, but I inverted the value, because using lerp speed would mean that "no inertia" would be +inf speed, while I find it more natural to have more inertia if the number is higher, zero consistenly turning it off as a result.

data.title: MethodBind: Adds operator== to compare by id
data.body: This way it's possible to search methods in `List` or `Vector`.

data.title: Editor: Remember update mode.
data.body: The state of the editor update mode (e.g. "Update Always") will be saved per project, in the metadata file.

data.title: Make build scripts Python 3 compatible
data.body:
SCons 3.0 alpha supports Python 3. These changes update the build files so that Godot can be built with Python 3 when using the new Scons version. 

I've tested the build process with Python 2.7 and 3.6 on Windows. I'm not sure if there are incompatibilities when building with Python < 2.7.

I haven't updated the build scripts for platforms other than Windows but I can do so if the consensus is that this is the right way to move forward.
